did.unittitle:
Jay Handler Schmidt papers
1918-1968
did.abstract: Alumnus of University of Michigan, and secretary of the University of Michigan Club of Suburban New Jersey. Correspondence and other materials relating to his alumni activities and his continuing interest in University affairs; and photographs.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was the gift of Jay Schmidt (donor no. 2139) and came to the library mainly in 1971 and 1974.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is not held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Jay Handler Schmidt papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Jay H. Schmidt graduated from the University of Michigan School of Engineering in 1916, with a degree in chemical engineering. He served in France during World War I, and did graduate work at the University of Montpellier (France) as a member of the Army School Detachment. In 1925, Schmidt founded Special Toiletries Corp., a contract cosmetics firm. He was president of the firm until his retirement in 1948.

Schmidt was a very loyal alumnus of the University of Michigan. He was a member of the University of Michigan Club of New York Scholarship Committee, an officer of the First District Alumni Association, and organizer and officer of the University of Michigan Club of Suburban New Jersey.

scopecontent.p: The Schmidt collection consists of 0.4 feet of papers covering the years 1918-1968, though concentrating in the period since 1944. There is a small folder of materials detailing his World War I service and a few letters concerning his interest in perfumes and fragrances. The collection also contains two folders and several letters relating to Schmidt's work as board member and fund-raiser on behalf of the University of Michigan Committee, Thomas E. Dewey for President, during the 1944 and 1948 elections. Much of the collection concerns other alumni activities, including a sample of letters relating to recruiting prospective students for the University of Michigan.
